title: ADB commits $4.22 B for Phl infra projects
text:
ADB commits $4.22 B for Phl infra projects By Czeriza Valencia   
  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has committed to lend $4.22 billion to the Philippines for development and infrastructure programs and extend technical assistance valued at $9.3 million until 2019. 
The multilateral fund’s new country operations and business plan (COBP) for the Philippines is aimed at helping the country achieve more inclusive growth and address income inequalities and regional disparities. 
Specifically, it will focus on four areas: sustainable and climate-resilient infrastructure, good governance and finance, inclusive employment and education, and regional integration. 
ADB said countries in developing Asia need to implement regulatory and institutional reforms to make infrastructure more attractive to private investors and generate a pipeline of bankable projects for public-private partnerships (PPP). 
In this aspect, ADB cited PPP practices in the Philippines as among the “most improving” in the region because of the government’s commitment to introduce well-prepared projects. 
ADB also recommended the development of capital markets to “help channel the region’s substantial savings into productive infrastructure investment.”   
Developing Asia and the Pacific need to invest $1.7 trillion annually to sustain its growth momentum, eradicate poverty and respond to climate change, ADB said in a report yesterday. 
The report, “Meeting Asia’s Infrastructure Needs,” estimates this financing need to reach $26 trillion from 2016 to 2030, factoring in the need to address climate change mitigation and adaptation needs. Without climate change costs, the region will need $22.6 trillion for the given period, an investment of $1.5 trillion per year. 
ADB’s new flagship report focuses on the region’s infrastructure needs for power, transport, telecommunications, and water sanitation. Considered in the compilation of the report are the region’s current infrastructure stocks and investments, future investment needs and financing mechanisms. 
Out of the total climate-adjusted investment needs from 2016 to 2030, $14.7 trillion is seen to be needed for power while $8.4 trillion is required for transport. Investments needed in telecommunications are seen to reach $2.3 trillion while needs for water and sanitation infrastructure are placed at $800 billion. 
“The demand for infrastructure across Asia and the Pacific far outstrips current supply,” said ADB president Takehiko Nakao. “Asia needs new and upgraded infrastructure that will set the standard for quality, encourage economic growth, and respond to the pressing global challenge that is climate change.” 
ADB said infrastructure development in developing Asia has “grown dramatically” in recent decades but a “substantial” infrastructure gap remains. Around 400 million people still lack access to electricity, 300 million lack access to safe drinking water and about 1.5 billion lack access to basic sanitation. 
Many economies in the region also lack adequate ports, railways, and roads that could connect them efficiently to larger domestic and global markets, said the report. 
Developing Asia currently invests an estimated $881 billion in infrastructure. The investment gap—the difference between investment needs and current investment levels—is around 2.4 percent of the projected gross domestic product of the region for 2016 to 2020, according to the report.
